body: hi, we do not currently have imputation methods in sktime that I am aware of, sorry. We would very much like to have some though!

You can get imputation through composition for any reduction method to a `sklearn` method, such as `DirectRegressionForecaster` - simply wrap a pipeline whose first element is a `sklearn` imputer, e.g., `SimpleImputer`.

Depending on your data format, you may also consider using `transformations.panel.interpolate` which can be used as imputer depending on the setting.

As @TonyBagnall says, contributions are welcome - e.g., an imputation transformer based on the interpolator.

Let's maybe briefly also check with @mloning whether we didn't forget another potential solution to your problem.
thanks Franz, my knowledge of sktime is localised to the classification side, I am not really best place to comment .... so probably shouldnt :)

@zhenlingcn is this in the context of forecasting? And you want to impute them before training the forecasting algorithm? If so, you could wrap some of pandas impute functionality in a transformer and use it in a pipeline perhaps?

Yes, the context is forecasting. I can use pandas to simply fill in the missing values, such as filling in the missing values by mean value. However, the filling function provided by pandas is rather simple. In fact, I hope I can use more advanced filling methods, such as linear or non-linear interpolation.

Hm, I thought interpolators (padding, last value carry forward, linear/smoothing) were on the forecasting wishlist #220 or some roadmap, but I can't find them. Should definitely be there, since there are time series specific missing value handling strategies that you won't get from scikit-learn. @mloning, @TonyBagnall, do we have this recorded in some roadmap issue?
There is a related issue on handling missing values #69

Linear and non-linear interpolation are also provided by numpy, SciPy or pandas. See for example: https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.interpolate.html

Since there isn't anything there, adding a simple `Interpolator` (series-to-series transformer) would be great! @zhenlingcn would you be interested in working on that? As a template take a look at the transformers here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/sktime/transformations/series/acf.py

issue.title: Added Imputer for missing values

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
#69 #603 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->
Transformation of `pd.Series` to impute missing values (`np.nan`) with different imputation strategies.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->
No
#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->
The imputation with `method="drift"` might be renamed to `"trend"`, however I adopted this naming from `sktime.NaiveForecaster`, so maybe we can rename it there also?

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->

1. I might implement further imputation  strategies, if s.o. has more ideas of other methods. 
2. I might also add an example to the notebook. 
3. What about imputation of `pd.DataFrame`, should this also be considered?

Example:
```python
from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.transformations.series.impute import Imputer

y = load_airline()

y[0] = np.nan
y[4] = np.nan
y[5] = np.nan
y[8] = np.nan

# with trend
imputer = Imputer(method="drift")
imputer.fit_transform(y)

# with any forecaster
imputer = Imputer(method="forecaster", forecaster=TBATS(sp=12, use_trend=True, use_box_cox=False))
imputer.fit_transform(y)
```

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/.all-contributorsrc).
- [x] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body: @zhenlingcn solved by #637 . I think it can be closed then.
